title: Labour throws lifeline to challenger banks in fight against Osborne tax | Money
text:
Attempts are being made to water down George Osborne’s new tax on all banks which make profits of more than £25m.
The measure, announced in the budget , has proved unpopular with the so-called challenger banks, which are attempting to break the stranglehold of Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds Banking Group, HSBC and Barclays, and with building societies, which also face being subjected to the new tax.
John Mann, a Labour MP on the Treasury select committee, has tabled an amendment to the finance bill to exempt any bank or building society from paying the tax if it has a balance sheet of less than £25bn – essentially the new entrants.
Related: Osborne faces wrath of challengers after placing himself in big banks' pockets
“My amendment will ensure that the smaller banks and building societies, who have lent responsibly, will not be adversely affected by these changes,” Mann said.
The tax was introduced alongside changes to the bank levy, which was applied to bank balance sheets and the subject of complaints from HSBC, which paid £700m as a result of the levy. The levy is to be scaled back and paid only on UK balance sheets, reducing the bill for HSBC which as an international bank had been paying a charge based on its global balance sheet.
Osborne is meeting representatives of challenger banks this week, including the boss of Metro Bank. When Metro launched in 2010 it was the first bank to open a new branch network on high streets for 100 years, and it is now reported to be pressing ahead with plans for a stock market flotation next year.
Standard & Poor’s says it expects the new 8% surcharge to “dampen the challenger banks’ profit ambitions in the near term”. It also pointed to the potential for a wave of mergers and acquisitions among the challengers. “We don’t expect all challenger banks to succeed in their aims, therefore consolidation appears inevitable to us,” the ratings agency said.
